On Fri, Dec 19, 2003 at 09:07:10PM -0800, David Goodwin wrote:
> ps - Regarding your problems compiling Cantera on a PC... I think 
the
> Windows Visual C++ project files have become out of date.  It has
> unfortunately become a bit cumbersome to build Cantera under 
Windows.
> You need not only Visual C++ and Compaq Visual Fortran, but also a
> unix-like environment (e.g. cygwin) so that some unix shell 
scripts can
> be run by the build process.

Ah.  So this would be why I've been having similar problems.  (I 
hadn't
quite gotten things sorted so as to properly ask about it,
though.)  We've also been having troubles with simply linking the
Cantera dll into another C application, but I'm not yet sure that 
this
isn't errors on our part.

If this linking problem is known part of the problem you mention with
the latest versions of Cantera, what version would be the latest that
still has in-date project files for use in Windows?

> The problem is exacerbated by the fact
> that Microsoft no longer sells Visual C++ 6.0, but Compaq (now HP?)
> Visual Fortran has not been updated to support Visual Studio .NET.

And this information, is itself now out of date.  Compaq Visual 
Fortran
became not HP, but Digital Visual Fortran.  This was bought by Intel,
with the intent of merging it with their compiler.  The 8.0 release 
of
Intel's Fortran compiler -- which just came out two weeks ago -- is 
the
successor to both Intel's 7.x compiler and to Visual Fortran.  And,
further, it _is_ fully integrated with Visual Studio .NET.

- Brooks
